thread.title: Dow jumps 200 points into black for the year as Street cheers Greece deal
thread.title_full: Dow jumps 200 points into black for the year as Street cheers Greece deal

title: Dow jumps 200 points into black for the year as Street cheers Greece deal
text:
Dow jumps 200 points into black for the year as Street cheers Greece deal By Evelyn Cheng 12 minutes ago ÓÅ± . View photo Lucas Jackson | Reuters. U.S. stocks opened higher on Monday, following overseas markets higher, on news of a bailout agreement between Greece and its creditors. 
U.S. stocks rallied nearly 1 percent or more on Monday, following gains overseas, on news of a bailout agreement between Greece and its creditors. ( Tweet This ) 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained about 200 points, recovering losses to trade in the black for the year, with DuPont ( DD ) and Goldman Sachs ( GS ) leading most blue chips higher. 
The Nasdaq Composite jumped more than 1 percent as Apple ( AAPL ) gained more than 1 percent and the iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF (IBB) ( IBB ) rose more than 1.5 percent. 
"I think it's just a sigh of relief that it's over, but let's face it, they just kicked the can," said Maris Ogg, president of Tower Bridge Advisors. "It seems like we kicked the can on a number of fronts. Earnings probably will be front and center int he next couple of weeks." 
Read More 'Agreekment!' Overnight talks result in deal with Greece 
European Council President Donald Tusk said early on Monday that euro zone leaders reached an unanimous agreement with Greece after all-night talks in Brussels to move forward with a bailout loan for the cash-strapped nation, provided Athens implement tough reforms. 
"The jury's still out on whether or not this is going to be accomplished," said Mark Luschini, chief investment strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott. 
The European Central Bank announced it maintains the emergency assistance cap for Greek banks, which will remain close for at least two more days. 
The Dow Jones industrial average futures were about 140 points higher before the open. 
European stocks jumped more than 1 percent, with the German DAX up about 1.2 percent and the STOXX Europe 600 up nearly 1.6 percent 
In Asia, stocks surged with the Nikkei up 1.57 percent and the Shanghai Composite leaping 2.4 percent as it extended a recovery from a recent plunge. 
Read More Traders could stay close to home in week ahead 
Art Hogan, chief market strategist at Wunderlich Securities, said the domestic response will likely be less exuberant since the major averages ended last week little changed. Only the Dow eked out a gain, of a mere 0.17 percent. 
Bond yields rose, with the U.S. 10-year at 2.45 percent and the 2-year yield at 0.67 percent. The German 10-year bund yield was 0.90 percent. 
The U.S. dollar gained half a percent, with the euro falling towards $1.10. 
No economic data or earnings of note are expected Monday. 
Second-quarter earnings season gets underway with a slew of major reports on Tuesday that include JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo . 
On the economic front, retail sales are due Tuesday morning. Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen delivers her semi-annual testimony on the economy to Congress on Wednesday and Thursday. 
Read More Early movers: AAPL, DEPO, JAH, MPC, SNE, UL & more 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average (Dow Jones Global Indexes: .DJI) traded up 140 points, or 0.80 percent, at 17,901, with DuPont leading gains and Exxon Mobil and Chevron the only decliners. 
The S&P 500 ( ^GSPC ) traded up 15 points, or 0.71 percent, at 2,091, with financials leading 10 sectors higher. 
The Nasdaq ( ^IXIC ) traded up 43 points, or 0.86 percent, at 5,040. 
About four stocks advanced for every decliner on the New York Stock Exchange, with an exchange volume of 53 million and a composite volume of 119 million in the open. 
Crude oil futures gained 66 cents to $52.08 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Gold futures fell $6.40 to $1,151.50 an ounce in morning trade. 
On tap this week:
